[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the presence of a robotic arm grasping a human arm's wrist, which appears to be dislocated. The arm is resting on a table. The task is to manipulate the wrist back into its correct position.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The coordinate frame is located at the grasped wrist with the Z-axis pointing upwards, the X-axis pointing to the right, and the Y-axis pointing forward.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward motion in the world. Positive motion would lift the wrist directly upwards. Negative motion would lower the wrist downwards, towards the table.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move slightly upwards to create space to maneuver the wrist.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to rightward motion in the world. Positive motion would move the wrist to the right, while negative motion moves the wrist to the left.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move slightly to the left or right to align the bones.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward motion in the world. Positive motion would push the wrist away from the robot, while negative motion would pull the wrist toward the robot.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move with slight forward and backward motion to align the bones.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved slightly upwards along the Z-axis, with slight lateral and longitudinal movement to manipulate the wrist back in place.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The object is a human wrist. We estimate the mass of the wrist and forearm segment being manipulated to be about 1 kg. The wrist joint itself exhibits significant stiffness and resistance to unwanted motion, especially when dislocated. The skin has a relatively high static friction coefficient against the robot gripper.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity is acting on the wrist. Friction between the arm and the table will resist lateral movements.
- The relevant object is the human wrist and lower forearm, which is assumed to be a soft tissue and bone composite. It has mass 1 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the table, which is assumed to be a relatively smooth surface. It has a static friction coefficient of 0.4 with the object.
- Contact Types: The robot maintains a pinch grasp on the wrist. The forearm also maintains surface contact with the table.
- Motion Type: The motion will involve a combination of lifting, lateral movement, and possible slight rotation.
- Contact Considerations: The robot needs to maintain a secure grasp throughout the manipulation. Vertical force may be needed to overcome friction and lift the wrist. Controlled motion in X and Y directions is required to manipulate the wrist joint.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts motion in a combination fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: The task duration is estimated to be approximately 5 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: mass of wrist and forearm (m) = 1 kg, coefficient of static friction (μ) = 0.6, acceleration due to gravity (g) = 9.81 m/s^2
- Relevant equations: F_friction = μ * F_normal, F = ma
- Relevant assumptions: The mass distribution is assumed to be uniform. The joint dislocation requires a force in each axis to set back in place.
- Computations: The force required to lift the wrist against gravity is approximately F = mg = 1 kg * 9.81 m/s^2 = 9.81 N. The force required to overcome static friction along the table is F_friction = 0.4 * 9.81 N = 3.92 N. Force required to overcome static friction from the gripper is approximately F_friction = 0.6 * 9.81N = 5.89 N
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: A force of 9.81 N is required to lift the arm in the Z direction to overcome gravity. A force of 3.92 N is required to move the wrist along the table.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon needing to exert a slight lateral corrective force to set the dislocated wrist, the object in the image must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 2 N.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon needing to exert a slight forward corrective force to set the dislocated wrist, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 2 N.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon needing to slightly lift the wrist to set the dislocated wrist, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 10 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon needing to possibly rotate the wrist to align it, the object in the image must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon needing to possibly rotate the wrist to align it, the object in the image must exert angular clockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the task goal requiring no rotation, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Grasping force: Estimated force range and justification based on friction, mass, resistance, thus 20 to 30 N .

```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The object is a human wrist with an estimated mass of 1 kg. It is made of bone and soft tissue, and has a static friction coefficient of 0.6 with the robot gripper and 0.4 with the table surface."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "The object must be moved slightly upwards along the Z-axis, and with slight lateral and longitudinal movements along the X and Y axes respectively to manipulate the wrist back in place. Small rotations may be necessary around the X and Y axes."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.01, 0.01, 0.01]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [2, 2, 10, 0.5, -0.5, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 25
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
